Marg Bhavnagar Gujarat 364002 India Cellulose is the most abundant organic source and has expedient a great deal of interest as renewable and emerged as sustainable feedstock. The functionalization of cellulose as designed catalytic system intriguing furnished to the production of fine chemicals. Herein, we synthesized an environmental friendly solid acid catalyst by functionalizing cellulose with phosphoric acid (PO3H). The successful functionalization of cellulose with PO3H was confirmed by 31P NMR, ICP-OES, FE-SEM, and XPS analysis. ICP-OES revealed the presence of phosphorus content of ∼1.0 wt. % on the catalyst's surface while elemental mapping by FESEM and XPS shows a uniform distribution of phosphorus over the material. The synthesized solid acid catalyst was utilized for condensation of diols with acetoacetic esters in solvent-free conditions to synthesize fine chemicals. The present approach not only circumvented the one-step protection and other products but more fascinatingly provided trans-esterification of acetoacetic esters with diols and n-alcohols. The catalyst was successfully used for chemoselective protection on ethyl acetoacetate with 1, 2 diols to essential fructone molecule with ∼100% conversion and 99% selectivity. The results suggested that the catalyst has the advantage over commercial solid acid heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cellulose Acetoacetic ester Protection Trans-esterification Fine chemicals 1 Introduction The utilization of renewable biomass to synthesize carbonaceous feedstock such as supports and functionalized catalysts for the synthesis of fuels and organic transformation into fine chemicals. Increasingly, the utilization of this agro-waste energy source has been targeted as a cleaner and more efficient alternative to thermal energy [1]. Subsequently, fine chemicals are widely used over the decades for the synthesis of many pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals [2]. Due to the requirement of high purity, technology intensiveness, and low cost, fine chemicals are always among the most active and strategic areas of research in the chemical industries [3]. Also, the demand and the global market exponentially increasing day by day for fine chemicals [3-5]. With the recent governmental strict regulatory requirements, the manufacturing processes of fine chemicals need to be substantially improved. Many researchers are trying to improve the existing processes by using different catalysts or finding alternative routes using different cost-effective reagents [6]. As an alternative, active methylene compounds (AMCs) have captured our intensive attention because of their multi-coupling activity and low-energy process to convert into high-value compounds. Therefore, the sustainable and efficient catalytic process to organic transformation of AMCs in fine chemicals has been furnished as a new significant approach [7-15]. For instance, our group reported more challenging one-pot synthesis of flavouring molecules via alkylation-decarboxylation of sub-benzylic alcohols and active methylene compounds [11]. Surprisingly, very few reports demonstrated these reactions of AMCs to value-added molecules, it seems sustainable and new life in fine chemistry. The active methylene compound widely attracts as a reagent to the scientific community to explore more productive methodologies. The use of AMCs towards the various fine chemicals appears as a promising option and greener route to fulfil the growing needs towards the fine chemical [7, 11, 15]. Notably, AMCs are multi-coupling reagents having electrophilic and nucleophilic sites and have successfully used in nucleophilic and electrophilic reactions. From the various AMCs the β-keto-ester is widely used to synthesize fine chemicals using a viable solid-acid catalytic system. Among them, the use of solid Brønsted-acid (BA) catalysts and AMCs have been reported to synthesize value-added chemicals like AMCs, fructone (ethyl 3, 3-ethylendioxybutyrate) is widely used in fragrance industries, cosmetics, food, beverages, and pharmaceuticals detergents, and lacquer industries, and it is used in perfumery industries due to the apple-like smell [16]. The flavoring material is synthesized via ethyl acetoacetate (EAA) acetalization with ethylene glycol using various BA catalysts [17,18]. Industrially, fructone was synthesized using sulphuric acid, p-toluenesulfonic acid, [17] hydrochloric acid. The utilization of acids possesses several issues, including product separation, corrosion of equipments, to name a few. In this regard, more focus is applied on the use of catalysts that can yield fructone without using acids as reagents. More recently, heterogeneous solid acid catalysts like resin-based solid-acid catalyst [19], zeolites [20], ionic liquids [21], heteropoly acids [22], and SO3H functionalized carbon materials [23] have attracted more attention in the fine chemical industries. For example, Liu et al. reported the acetalization of EAA with ethylene glycol using ionic liquid [BSEt3N] [HSO4] with 61% conversion of EAA and 50-65% isolated yields [17]. In 2010, Hu and coworkers reported fructone synthesis by SO3H functionalized carbon catalysts, with the efficiency of 99% conversion and 99% selectivity [23]. Recently, cesium exchanged Al-SBA-15 catalyst has been used in the synthesis of fructone [22]. However, these catalysts suffer various drawbacks: low activity, economically unfavourable, by-products formation, excess solvent utilization, and limited substrate scope. Additionally, reported literature reports suggest that to achieve facile protection and conventional trans-esterification reaction pose a tough challenge and demand specially designed substrates or catalysts to defeat these undesired trails. Biomass is accepted as the most auspicious renewable source of organic carbon available is the perfect equivalent of carbon-based materials. Therefore, exploring an effective approach to transforming biomass resources into catalysts is useful for catalyzing chemicals and fuels. Thus, such an approach has becomes so widespread that it attracts much attention from scientific research. Additionally, triggering these highly functionalized feeds selectively on “strongly and weakly acidic” ingredients. Designing new solid-acid catalysts efficient process could stand for these alternative feedstocks [24-27]. Thus, the use of agro-waste derived, naturally occurring molecules and post-functionalization by different acidic group processes can be a solution to the drawbacks further these catalytic materials remain underdeveloped and need to be focussed. Considering all the above-mentioned factors, the area of interest by chemists has been shifted towards the development of sustainable protocols for the synthesis of fine chemicals. In earlier reports, various metals and acidic functional groups were used to synthesize cellulose-based catalysts [26]. Among them, a cellulose-based magnetic nano-composite supported SO3H group was used as a catalyst for facile synthesis of functionalized pyrimido [4, 5-b] quinolines and indeno fused pyrido [2, 3-d] pyrimidines in water [27]. Kadam et al. had synthesized carbon-sulfur bond formation by exploring the cellulose sulfonic acid (CSA). The utilization of this cellulose sulfonic acid can function as a single source for both carbon and sulfonic groups to dithioacetal protection of carbonyl compounds [28]. Considering the greener and sustainable aspects, bio-derived polymers such as cellulose, chitin, chitosan, and dextrin have gained significant attention in the organic transformation [29-32]. Remarkably, cellulose is cheap and abundantly available all over the earth. The annual production of cellulose is 75 to 100 billion tonnes and can be considered as a raw material for the synthesis of catalysts, chemicals, and fuels [33]. For instance, cellulose-supported various metal nanoparticles are widly utilized in alkylation, thiol protection, and isomerization reactions [28, 34, 36]. Hence, in the present work, the synthesis of a highly sustainable and cost-effective cellulose-PO3H functionalized catalyst has been tried for the first time to the best of our knowledge. The as-synthesized C-PO3H catalyst was used to protect acetoacetic ester (AAE) and trans-esterification reactions to fine chemical synthesis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cellulose, Ethyl acetoacetate (EAA, >99%), Methyl acetoacetate (MAA 99%), Ethyl 2-methyl-3-oxobutanoate (SMA, 98%). 1, 2, 1, 3 and 1, 4 diols from and triethylamine (99%) TCI Chemicals (India) Pvt. Ltd. 1-phenylbutane-1, 3-dione and 1-diphenylbutane-1, 3-dione (98%) (Sigma-Aldrich Chemicals company) were purchased and used without further purification. Concentrated Phosphorous trichloride (98% purity) was purchased from S. D. Fine Chemicals. The n-propanol and butanol were purchased from (Spectrochem) and used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of phosphoric acid-functionalized cellulose The phosphoric acid-functionalized solid catalyst was synthesized using cellulose as the renewable organic carbon. Typically, in a 100 mL two-neck round bottom flask (RBF), 5 g of cellulose was dispersed in 20 mL toluene and 5 mL Et3N and stirred at 400 rpm for 30 min. Then 10 mL of PCl3 was added dropwise through the syringe, and the reaction mixture was heated at 80°C for 7 h. After completing the reaction, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the excess amount of PCl3 was evaporated. The collected solid was washed three times with 25 mL isopropanol (IPA). The in-situ functionalization on cellulose gave a light brownish material, dried in a hot air oven at 100°C for 24 h. The final weight of the obtained brownish phosphoric acid-functionalized catalyst was 3.3 g and was labelled as C-PO3H. The structural characterization and content of phosphorous studies of the catalyst were carried out by different physicochemical methods shown below in detail and ESI page S2. 2.3 Catalytic activity: chemoselective protection reaction of AAE and diols In a typical reaction, a 50 mL round bottom flask (RBF) was charged with 7.6 mmol EAA, 8 mmol 1, 2 diol, and 80 mg C-PO3H. Further, the reaction mixture was stirred at 120°C for 6 h. The progress of the reaction was monitored by withdrawing the samples periodically and analyzing them by gas chromatography (GC) and calculated conversion, selectivity. After completion of the reaction, the solution was cooled to room temperature (30°C), the catalyst was separated by normal filtration and washed with iso-propyl alcohol and activated in oven at 100°C, 4 h for further reuse. The crude obtained was filtered, extracted using ethyl acetate and characterized by GC-MS techniques. The reaction was monitored by taking aliquots at different time intervals. These aliquots were analyzed by gas chromatography (Agilent GC 7890B) equipped with HP-5 capillary column of 30 m x 0.250 mm x 0.25 μm dimension and a FID detector and GC-MS (Shimadzu, GC-MS QP 2010, Japan). The products of the reaction were identified by comparing their retention time and/or by comparing the MS spectra with the reference standards when available. The reproducibility of the results was ensured by repeated experiments under identical conditions and was found to be consistent within ± 5% variation. 2.4 Trans-esterification reaction of AAE and n-alcohols In a typical reaction protocol, 7.6 mmol EAA, 8 mmol n-alcohol and 80 mg C-PO3H were heated at 120°C in 50 mL RBF for 6 h. The reaction mixture was heated at 120°C and the progress of the reaction was monitored by GC. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated by normal filtration washed with IPA and activated in the oven at 100°C, 4 h for further reuse. The solution was extracted and successfully characterized by GC-MS as mentioned in section 2.3. 3 Results and discussion The use of cellulose to functionalize the acidic and basic group is an attractive topic of research. Also, it is believed that the phosphoric group shows excellent catalytic activity towards the synthesis/development of valuable products. The synthesis of the acidic (PO3H) functionalized material was carried out by reaction of cellulose with PCl3. It is well known that phosphorous has a high affinity towards oxygen. Hence, when the cellulose is treated with highly reactive PCl3, oxygen moiety interacts with phosphorous to form O-P and P=O stable bonds which can be depicted from Scheme 1 . The high reactivity of PCl3 enhances various applications for phosphate, phosphine, phosphite, and acidic PO3H group functionalization. The functionalized material of cellulose has occurred as polymeric form. The surface area of the Cellulose-PO3H was measured using a N2 adsorption–desorption study at 77 K. The BET surface area of the catalyst was 28.65 m²/g and pore volume 0.02 while pore diameter is ∼27 Å. The less surface area was observed due to functionalized material of cellulose was metal-free and in polymeric form. [37-42]. However, for further structural information of the catalyst is explained in detail via different physico chemical techniques. 4 Catalyst Characterisation PXRD was used for the study of the phase purity of C-PO3H materials. The characteristic diffraction peaks of the synthesized catalysts were depicted in (Fig. 1A.). The characteristic peaks observed at 2 θ = 15.4°, 22.4°, 34.2° corresponded to cellulose corroborated with to literature reports [22-24]. Interestingly, after functionalization of cellulose with acidic PO3H group, the XRD data were significantly different, and there was the shifting of peaks corresponding to 2 θ value from 15.4-15.8°, 22.4-23.1°, to 2 θ = 25.5°, 27.9°, 33.4°, 35°, 43.4° and 47.2° observed. From these data, it was confirmed that the functionalization of the cellulose with phosphoric acidic group occurred respectively [36]. As seen in the XRD pattern of C-PO3H, the position and the relative intensities of observed peaks are different due to the phosphoric group [37-39]. Further, the functional hybrid framework of C-PO3H was confirmed by FT-IR and 31P NMR [40]. In the FTIR spectrum, the stronger band appears at 998 cm− 1 were corresponds to P-O-H bending vibrations, while the band at 960 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibrations of the acidic P-OH group. Correspondingly, the intensity of basic hydroxyl groups at 3448 cm−1 was reduced due to the replacement of the O-H to O-P bond. Additionally, the weak band appeared at 1174 cm−1 related to P=O stretching vibrations, and the new band appeared at 2674 and 2486 cm−1 stretching vibrations of the P-O bond, was observed in Fig. 1C. Principal Component Analysis (PCA): applied to both the survey and high resolution C 1s, O1s, and P 2p spectral data sets shows that there are two components present in both data sets shown in ESI figure S52 fig C [63]. 5 Catalytic Activity 5.1 Synthesis of Fructone from Diol and AAE The addition of the diol with AAE results in the formation of various cyclic ketals, which are widely used in the fine and fragrance chemical industries. Mainly fructone is commonly used in the perfumery industry [46-61]. The formation of fructone can be observed in scheme 2 . We began our studies using ethylene glycol with EAA as a model substrate and using different homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. Our initial investigation into this proposed condensation reaction of EAA and 1, 2-diol began with the catalyst variation studies is shown in (Table 1 ). When the reaction was tested in the absence of the catalyst, only a 10% conversion of the EAA was observed (Table 1, entry 1). However, H2SO4 and PTSA was shown the complete conversion of EAA with 60% and 65% selectivity towards fructone (Table 1, entries 2 and 3). The sulfamic acid gives almost 90% conversion of EAA with 50% selectivity of desired cyclic ketal (Table 1, entry 4). The low selectivity can be attributed to the strong acidity of H2SO4 and PTSA and intact the side reactions. However, the homogeneous nature of those catalysts makes the catalyst non-recyclable. Instead of homogeneous catalysts, various heterogeneous catalysts were tested for regioselective protection of EAA. The commercial Indion-190 gave 60% conversion of EAA with 70% selectivity of fructone (Table 1, entry 5). Amberlyite-IR-120H and Amberlyst-15 as Brønsted acid catalyst gave 71 and 70% selectivity of fructone (Table 1, entries 6 and 7). After investigating SO3H functionalized groups, we explored some PO3H functionalized catalysts under optimized conditions to protect the carbonyl functionality of EAA. The H3PO3 resulted in complete conversion of EAA with 20% selectivity of fructone, whereas using Phospotungstic acid, only 40% selectivity of fructone was observed. The heterogenized Silver-Phospotungstic acid gives an 80% conversion of EAA with 45% selectivity of fructone (Table 1, entries 9, 10 &11). Remarkably, the more amount and strong acidity of catalysts gave by-products like self-Aldol of EAA (EAA, 1, 2 diol, 120mg catalyst) and unwanted cyclization shown in ESI. Thus, the need for mild acidic conditions for this transformation is the need of the hour, which can easily help in selective synthesis of fructone. Herein, In-situ functionalized C-PO3H catalyst is used for further investigations. The C-PO3H catalyst gives promising results with 100% conversion of EAA with 99% selectivity of fructone. Similarly, previously reported Cellulose-SO3H (CSA) was prepared according to the literature procedure [62]. However, as compared to our catalyst, the CSA has given complete conversion but intercept in the selectivity of fructone (Table 1, entry 13). Notably, the strong acidity hurdle to conversion in the selectively desired product. Similarly, phosphorous doped carbon was used as catalyst, but there was no significant change in conversion and selectivity to fructone as the desired product. Overall, sulfonated functional group/carbon catalysts usually afforded a higher conversion with a low selectivity. The results in the characterization sections was supply us more information about the structure-activity relationship of these –Cellulose-PO3H catalysts in the chemoselctive protection reaction. It can therefore be speculated that condensation of EAA and diols takes place at external acidic sites of C-PO3H. However, from the catalyst the -PO3H group creates acidic sites for the condensation and trans-esterification reaction. However, the functionalised group –PO3H can be used to convert reactant into product. Notably, the remaining hydroxyl groups on surface of catalyst can be creates acidity of the C-PO3H. However, the easily protonation occurred in the case of -PO3H group. The active acidic species easily protonate to carbonyl group and activated in enhanced electrophilic carbonyl group. Thus, to motif on selectivity and the high activity of C-PO3H, the C-PO3H is selected for further optimization of reaction parameters of protection and trans-esterification shown in Schemes 3 and 4 (Table 1, entry 12). The effect of catalyst amount on the regioselective protection of EAA with diols was explored by varying the catalyst amount from 20 to 120 mg, and the results are shown in Table S1 (Supporting information ESI). The 20 mg loading of catalyst was gave only 50% conversion of EAA. However, the conversion of EAA increased with the increase in the catalytic amount 80 mg showed 100% conversion and 99% selectivity of desired products, whereas the selectivity of fructone remained the same upon increasing the catalytic amount from 20 to 80 mg (Table S1 entry 3). Furthermore, increasing the catalyst amount to 120 mg, a complete conversion of EAA was observed with low selectivity (Table S1 entry 4). It was observed that the highest amount of catalytic sites present on the catalyst initiates the unwanted side reactions due to an increase in the acidity of the catalyst. The formed fructone was further undergoing the trans-esterification reactions to form the fructone esters. Thus, 80 mg of catalyst amount is considered as the optimum loading to get a maximum conversion of EAA (100%) with maximum selectivity of fructone (> 99%). 5.2 Solvent variation After optimizing catalyst variation and concentration of catalyst studies, we have further explored the effect of solvents in the condensation reaction. Herein we examined the high boiling point solvents for reported reaction. As per previous reports, ionic liquids as a solvent favour the formation of the fructone as the product, and non-polar solvents like toluene favour the formation of both products. For example, the reaction between EAA and ethylene glycol using C-PO3H in the presence of toluene and xylene gave complete conversion of EAA with 70-71% selectivity of fructone (Table S2, entries 1 and 2). The non-polar solvent does not hurdle to form the desired product. On the other hand, highly polar solvents like DMSO, DMF, and DMA yielded 40-45% conversion of EAA with 50-52% selectivity of fructone may attribute due to unwanted side reaction (Table S2, entries 3, 4, and 5). Therefore, from the solvent variation study, it can be inferred that non-polar solvents play an important role in protecting EAA. Thus, we compete with the extraction of non-polar solvent, and from our knowledge, sol-free reaction conditions may ease the isolation and result in eco-friendly conditions. The recyclability of catalyst studies under the optimized conditions was performed to check the variation in the activity of the catalyst for the subsequent cycles. The catalyst was separated after the reaction by a simple filtration technique. As a result, the catalyst was recycled 5 times (Shown in Fig. 5 ) and the catalyst was characterized by FT-IR and FE-SEM after the recyclability studies. (See ESI Fig S2 and S3). 6 Substrate scope To our delight, given the challenges in previous literature were to obtain the different types of chemoselective protected ketone with different diols and limited substrate scope. The expanded substrate scope, with a particular focus on the AAEs functional group tolerance towards the novel C-PO3H-catalyzed condensation was determined. We began with 1, 2 diols through the various AAEs, the experimental results apparent of fructone gave complete conversion with excellent selectivity 99% (Table 4 , entry 1). Similar results were obtained, using MAA with 95% conversion and 99% selectivity, whereas using Ethyl 2-methyl-3-oxobutanoate, the decreased conversion by 80% (Table 4, entries 2 and 3). In further studies, instead of 1, 2 ethane diols, the 1, 2 propanediol was used for the same reaction condition. It was observed that the selectivity and conversion did not affect the selectivity of the desired product (Table 4, entries 5-7). However, using benzylic carbonyl and acetyl carbonyl, the reaction was regioselectively taking place over the acetyl carbonyl (Table 4, entry 4). The 80-85% selectivity observed in 1-phenylbutane-1, 3-dione on chemoselective carbonyl, however increasing equivalence of diol, the diol selectively attacks on benzylic carbonyl (Table 4, entries 4 and 8). Furthermore, in the case of 1, 3 butane diol and AAE, 40-55% conversion and moderate to excellent selectivity towards the desired products was observed (Table 4, entries 9-11). Correspondingly, we finally applied these optimized reaction conditions on an increasing chain length of diol i.e., 1, 4 diols and 1, 5 diol. To our surprise, trans-esterification product was observed instead of the expected fructone. This may be attributed to the steric hindrance and ring stability. We next tested this protocol's applicability with 1, 4 diols and n-alcohols under optimum conditions (Table 5 ). The catalyst amount and time are the keys towards regioselectivity and chemoselectivity. Herein, when the high amount of catalyst is used, it resulted in the trans-esterification reaction instead of condensation. The trans-esterification reaction has also occurred with condensation when the equivalence amount of diol and the equivalent amount of catalyst increased is used (Table 5, entries 1-4). The identity of these products was further confirmed by GC-MS techniques with their standards. Furthermore, we tested few linear alcohols under the optimized conditions. It was observed that the catalyst showed excellent activity and selectivity towards the trans-esterification reaction. In this regard, we began the reaction of n-propyl alcohol and EAA under optimised reaction conditions, it resulted in almost complete conversion of EAA with 75% selectivity (Table 5, entry 5). The same result was observed with n-butyl alcohol and IPA showing 99% conversion and 70-65 respectively selectivity (Table 5, entries 6 and 7). On considering all these facts, we described the best reaction conditions for 1, 2 diols, and AEE with five/six-membered stable ring formation. Also, the model reaction was conducted at a 10 gm scale with an optimized reaction condition; it was observed that there was no change with respect to selectivity and conversion. This indicates the developed method is favourable as well as sustainable for scale-up at the industrial level. This is the beginning and the concept of justifiable development forms the basis of the environmental rules and strategies for moving towards a more sustainable pattern of economic development. Leaching and recycling studies: After the reaction completion catalyst was separated, the sample was taken from the reaction mixture and subjected to ICP acid digestion (Nitric and hydrochloric acid at a 1:3 ratio). The leaching studies were performed using ICP-AES analysis and it was found that negligible leaching occurred; as the phosphorous content remained intact and confirms its existence in the catalyst moiety. However, also, to check the leaching of –PO3H acidic sites, a hot filtration experiment was carried out by filtering the catalyst after 20 min and the filtrate was further allowed to react. No significant change in the conversion of EAA was found and data perfectly matched with ICP. To determine the pathway towards the catalytic synthesis of fructone, and to enable the readers as to how the reaction occurs, we have tried to present our data in the form of a plausible mechanism. The plausible mechanism is depicted in Scheme 5 . The catalyst initially protonates the carbonyl group in the EAA to give respective oxonium ion Scheme 5. This oxonium ion stabilizes hydroxyl groups of 1, 2 diols to give hemiacetal. After the formation of hemiacetal, the hydroxyl groups again get protonated by the catalyst and form an intermediate along with water moiety. Later the other side of the hydroxyl group present in 1, 2 diols are attacked and depart the water molecule resulting in the cyclization and to form the stable five-membered ring shown in scheme 5. The formation of cyclized product is detected by MS analysis Base peak at m/z = 87(100), 159 (the detailed information is presented in the ESI: S10). Furthermore, trans-ester products could also be detected through mass spectrometry peaks at m/z = Base peak: 43(100), 103(For detailed ESI: S23). This shows that the catalyst is not only active towards the synthesis of fructone from EAA and diols but is also recyclable and can be used for the gram-scale process. 7 Conclusion In summary, a green, efficient and heterogeneous acid catalyst, Cellulose-PO3H, was prepared and thoroughly characterized. The presence of phosphoric acid group (PO3H) was confirmed by 31P-NMR, FT-IR, CHNS and XPS analysis. The synthesized material was used as the catalyst for fine chemical syntheses like protected ester, fructone, and trans-esterification products with ∼100% conversion and 99% selectivity. The cellulose-PO3H catalyst can be considered as the green and recoverable catalyst for organic transformations. The catalyst was applicable for the regio and chemoselective organic transformation. Also, the catalyst showed efficient recyclability as the catalyst depicted similar activity for five consecutive cycles. The additional application of a further reaction step and selectivity control towards protected ester, and trans-esterification seems promising and will be part of ongoing industrial research. coredata.dc:description: Cellulose is the most abundant organic source and has expedient a great deal of interest as renewable and emerged as sustainable feedstock. The functionalization of cellulose as designed catalytic system intriguing furnished to the production of fine chemicals. Herein, we synthesized an environmental friendly solid acid catalyst by functionalizing cellulose with phosphoric acid (PO3H). The successful functionalization of cellulose with PO3H was confirmed by 31P NMR, ICP-OES, FE-SEM, and XPS analysis. ICP-OES revealed the presence of phosphorus content of ∼1.0 wt. % on the catalyst's surface while elemental mapping by FESEM and XPS shows a uniform distribution of phosphorus over the material. The synthesized solid acid catalyst was utilized for condensation of diols with acetoacetic esters in solvent-free conditions to synthesize fine chemicals. The present approach not only circumvented the one-step protection and other products but more fascinatingly provided trans-esterification of acetoacetic esters with diols and n-alcohols. The catalyst was successfully used for chemoselective protection on ethyl acetoacetate with 1, 2 diols to essential fructone molecule with ∼100% conversion and 99% selectivity. The results suggested that the catalyst has the advantage over commercial solid acid heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Brønsted acidic cellulose-PO3H: An efficient catalyst for the chemoselective synthesis of fructones and trans-esterification via condensation of acetoacetic esters with alcohols and diols
